text: Randi Zuckerberg Twitter debuted on the
stock exchange this morning and
experienced that was pretty fraught for
Facebook what do you think Facebook
learned from that whole experience gosh
well I think every company that you see
is learning from the companies that came
before it Facebook certainly learned a
lot from the IPOs that came before us I
I do think you know I've been on my kind
of media book tour blitz all day so I
haven't quite had a chance to dive into
the opening day but it looks like it has
been very very successful for Twitter
and personally I remember when I first
recognized Twitter as a site to be
reckoned with on the social media scene
and I write a lot about that in my book
so it's exciting to see where they are
today did you ever dream that both
Facebook and Twitter would be trading on
Wall Street gosh no no I'd never dreamed
that but it's really exciting to see two
companies both of which I feel like I
was there from the beginning of because
I had so many friends who were there in
the early days of Twitter and still
there and it's just it seems like such a
new exciting world your book is all
about how we untangle are wired live
something that I know I struggle with so
what's your number one tip for all of us
I think my number one tip is to be your
authentic self now it used to be that we
felt we needed to be someone very
different in our professional life
someone at homes someone with our
friends but the interesting reality of
today's wired world is that you really
only get one identity online all it
takes is someone with a savvy google
searching ability or the fact that we're
now facebook friends with our colleagues
and our families know everything about
our work lives that all it takes is a
little bit of searching to uncover
everything about us so it really is very
important to be your authentic self and
remember that you kind of only get one
identity online now so you need to think
it through pretty carefully so you mean
if we're authentic we can't possibly get
into trouble but what if we massively
overshare that there's definitely such a
thing as oversharing first Shore I talk
about that a lot in the book
in fact the context I talk about that a
lot is you speak to a lot of parents who
are very concerned about their teenagers
on social media their young kids sharing
and they'll tell you that they're
concerned and then they'll go and be
over sharers themselves so one of the
other key takeaways from my book is that
especially as parents in this digital
age we need to really take stock of our
own behavior in while we're looking at
how to effectively raise this digital
generation and what made you realize it
was time to disconnect a bit more for me
it was definitely having my own son was
that huge aha wake up moment in my life
I had been at Facebook for six years
non-stop and the mo in Silicon Valley is
everyone's thinking about what can we
disrupt right now what are we innovating
in right now what are we building now
but it was really having my son that
made me start thinking about the future
that made me think do I really do I want
him to grow up in this world where we're
expected to be connected 24/7 glued to
smartphones answering emails seconds
after they come in is that really the
answer and if it's not the answer I felt
I had some responsibility to spark that
discussion now being Mark Zuckerberg
sister you were told meant you had to be
three times as good as any man just to
get to where they were is that still
true today or if you moved beyond that
I'm trying to move beyond that and make
my own name which is why I'm so excited
about my books that are coming out
because I feel like this is really my
ability to tell my own story but you're
absolutely right I talk a lot in the
book about the glass half full and half
empty reality for me of having such a
famous last name in Silicon Valley on
one hand there were I'm so thankful for
so many of the opportunities that being
part of the Zuckerberg family has
unlocked for me both at Facebook and
Beyond Facebook but on the other hand
you know it's really interesting to go
about your life living in the shadow of
such a successful sibling and struggling
to make your own mark on the world so
hopefully with these books I can start
to do that Randi Zuckerberg the
you so much for joining us thank you
